sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Microbial transformation
Stevioside
Diterpenoid
Filamentous fungi
Cytokine
A B S T R A C T

Transformation of 15-ene steviol ( ent -13-hydroxy-kaur-15-en-19-oic acid) by growth cultures of
Aspergillus niger BCRC
32720,
Cunninghamella bainieri ATCC
9244, and
Mortierella isabellina ATCC
38063 was conducted to generate various derivatives for the development of bioactive compounds. Four previously undescribed compounds along with six known compounds were obtained. The newly identified isolates were characterized using 1D and 2D NMR, IR, and HRESIMS, and three compounds were further confirmed by X-ray crystallographic analyses. Subsequently, the effects of 15-ene steviol and its derivatives on lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced cytokine production by THP-1 cells were examined, with dexamethasone used as a positive control. Results indicated that most of the tested compounds showed lower inhibitory effects than those detected in the dexamethasone-treated group, except that 15-ene steviol showed better effects than dexamethasone on the reduction of LPS-induced monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP)-1, 2, and 3 release. Three specialized products similarly showed better effects than dexamethasone on the inhibition of LPS-induced secretion of regulated on activation, normal T cell expressed and secreted (RANTES). Moreover, none of the tested compounds showed any cytotoxicity or triggered cell apoptosis, and none affected the protein integrity of toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) or MyD88, suggesting that these compounds may exert the anti-inflammatory activity downstream of membrane-associated TLR4 and MyD88 molecules.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: 2. Results and discussion
2.1. Bioconversion of 15-ene steviol (2) by A. niger BCRC 32720, C. bainieri ATCC 9244, and M. isabellina ATCC 38063
a Assignments based on DEPT, HSQC, and HMBC. b Signal multiplicity and coupling constants (Hz) are in parentheses. c Overlapping signals.

Compound 9 showed a molecular formula of C 20 H 30 O 4 by HRESIMS data ([M + Na] + at m/z 357.2030 and [M H] at 333.2057). The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra showed similar resonances as those of 2 . However, the DEPT spectra revealed the disappearance of one tertiary carbon and the presence of one quaternary carbon resonating at δ 75.7 when compared with 2 ( Table 1 ; Figs. S21 and S22, Supplementary data). Thus, the lack of a carbinol-methine signal and the disappearance of one tertiary carbon in the 1 H NMR and DEPT spectra of 9 suggested that the new hydroxyl group was introduced at C- 5 or C- 9. In the 13 C NMR spectrum, C- 11 was shifted from δ 22.0 in 2 to δ 33.4 in 9 . CH 3 -20 was also significantly shifted downfield to δC 18.0 (Δδ + 1.7 ppm) and δH 1.47 (Δδ + 0.23 ppm) in the NMR spectra vs. 2 , suggesting that a hydroxyl group might reside at C- 9 ( Table 1 ). In the HSQC and HMBC spectra, CH 3 -20 (δ 1.47), H-7 (δ 1.57), H-11 (δ 1.77), H-12 (δ 2.01), H-11 (δ 2.34), and H-14 (δ 2.83) showed connectivities with δC 75.7, suggesting the presence of an OH group at C- 9 ( Fig. 2 ; Figs. S23 S26, Supplementary data). On the basis of the above analysis, 9 was established as ent -9α,13-dihydroxy-kaur-15-en-19-oic acid.

Compound 11 was obtained as white needles, and its molecular formula, C 20 H 30 O 4 , was established from HRESIMS data ( m/z 335.2229 [M +H] + , calcd 335.2222) and the 13 C NMR and DEPT spectra. The 1 H, 13 C NMR, and HSQC spectra were similar to those of 2 except for new resonances at δH 4.74 and δC 71.1 ( Table 1 ; Figs. S31 S34, Supplementary data). In the HMBC spectrum, the new resonance at δH 4.74 showed connectivities with resonances at δC 25.9 ( CH 3 -18), 35.6 (H-1), and 49.4 (H-5), indicating the presence of an OH group at C- 3 ( Fig. 2 ; Figs. S35 and S36, Supplementary data). The β- orientation of 3-OH was suggested from cross-peaks of δH 4.74 (H-3) with resonances at δH 1.76 ( CH 3 -18), 2.01 (H-2), and 2.76 (H-2) ( Fig. 3 ; Figs. S37 and S38, Supplementary data). Moreover, the single-crystal X-ray crystallographic experiment confirmed that 11 was ent -3α,13-dihydroxy-kaur-15-en-19- oic acid ( Fig. 4 ).

sec.title: 2.2. Biological evaluation
sec.p:
Boonkaewwan et al. reported that stevioside suppresses LPS-evoked tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α and interleukin (IL)-1β release, which is probably in part via the toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)/IKKβ/nuclear factor (NF)-κB pathway (
). Because 15-ene steviol ( 2 ) is derived from stevioside, we analyzed the bioactivity of 2 and its bioconverted derivatives in LPS-stimulated cytokine release by THP-1 cells, using dexamethasone as a positive control. After 24 h of treatment, dexamethasone significantly reduced TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-1β mRNA levels as analyzed by an RT-qPCR. Stevioside also decreased LPS-evoked IL-6 and IL-1β expression. Compounds 3 and 9 significantly reduced both TNF-α and IL-6 mRNA levels; whereas 2 , 4 , 10 , and 12 only decreased IL-6 expression. Overall, these compounds were less active than dexamethasone ( Table S1 , Supplementary data). Next, culture medium was collected and subjected to a human cytokine array to assess the effects of the tested compounds on LPS-induced cytokine secretion. After quantification and normalization to the LPS-treated group, the results showed that dexamethasone completely abolished LPS-induced granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) release, and reduced secretion of IL-1β, IL-6, and macrophage-derived chemokine (MDC/CCL22) to approximately 60% levels. Dexamethasone also decreased the secretion of RANTES/CCL5 and TNF-α to about 70% levels ( Fig. 5 ). However, stevioside only suppressed LPS-induced monocyte chemoattractant protein (MCP)-3 (CCL7), macrophage colony-stimulating factor (MCSF), and MDC secretion to about 50% levels ( Fig. 5 ). Most of the tested compounds showed lower inhibitory effect than those detected in the dexamethasone-treated group. However, compound 2 seemed to have better effect than dexamethasone on reducing LPS-induced MCP-1 (CCL2), 2 (CCL8), and 3 (CCL7) secretion; compounds 10–12 showed similar and better inhibitory effect on LPS-induced RANTES secretion compared to dexamethasone ( Fig. 5 ). Although the cytokine secretion profile was not fully comparable to the mRNA expression profile as shown by the RT-qPCR analysis, this could be because some cytokines were produced by proteolytic cleavage of membrane-bound precursors or some might have been stored in traffic vesicles ready for release upon stimulation. In the present study, we analyzed cytokine mRNAs and cytokines released at 24 h after treatment; therefore, both cytokine mRNAs and secreted cytokines might not show parallel expression levels. In addition, all tested compounds at a 10 μM concentration did not show cytotoxicity toward 100 ng /mL LPS-treated THP-1 cells, as analyzed by an MTT assay (Fig. S41
A , Supplementary data). There was no apparent caspase-3 cleavage, further supporting that no cell damage or death occurred under the experimental conditions (Fig. S41 B , Supplementary data). Moreover, the integrity of TLR4 and its adaptor protein, MyD88, remained at similar levels (Fig. S41 C , Supplementary data), suggesting that the anti-inflammatory effect of these compounds might not interfere with signal reception, but possibly act through downstream TLR4/MyD88 signaling pathway
.

sec.title: 2.3. Molecular docking studies
3. Conclusions
sec.p:
The three microbial strains selected for this study were able to hydroxylate 2 .
M. isabellina
was able to hydroxylate 2 at C- 3, -9, and -17. The formation of compound 4 with an ether bridge between C- 11 and C-16 by
A. niger
and
M. isabellina
might have occurred in the same manner as in a previous report on the microbial transformation of ent -kaurenes (
). It might have formed during extraction with an aqueous acid. Thus, it is likely that compound 4 was formed by concomitant hydroxylation at the 11β position and bioepoxidation at the 15-double bond as an intermediate, followed by protonation and opening of the oxirane ring, and then neutralization of the cation formed at C- 16 by attacking the 11β- OH. In addition,
C. bainieri
had the ability to introduce an OH group at C- 9 and also to rearrange the ent -kaurene into an ent -beyerane skeleton as in our previous report (
). Additionally, the bioactivity results presented herein suggest that the anti-inflammatory effect of these compounds might not act through cell membrane signaling transduction, but occur downstream of the TLR4/MyD88 pathway. Despite that the interaction energies of 2 and its derivatives to the GR were not as strong as that of dexamethasone, suppression of MCP or RANTES secretion in LPS-induced THP-1 cells and evidence of their molecular docking to the GR may provide molecular insights into the functions of 2 and
10–12 in
activating consecutive regulatory processes, especially in their anti-inflammatory effect. Further work is necessary to confirm their functions in cytokine secretion associated with inflammation. Additionally, based on results of this study, we successfully produced undescribed and useful specialized products using the microbial transformation technique.

sec.title: 4.1. General
sec.p:
Melting points were determined with a Yanagimoto micromelting point apparatus (Yanagimoto Ltd., Seisakusho, Japan ) and are uncorrected. IR data were obtained on a JASCO FT/IR-4000 spectrometer (Jasco, Tokyo , Japan ). Optical rotations were measured on a JASCO DIP-1020 digital polarimeter (Jasco, Tokyo , Japan ). The 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra in pyridine-
d 5
were recorded on a Bruker Avance-500 spectrometer (Bruker, Bremerhaven, Germany ). Chemical shifts are reported in parts per million (ppm) with respect to the corresponding solvent as the internal reference, and coupling constants ( J ) are in hertz (Hz). Low-resolution (LR)- and HRESIMS were obtained on a VG platform electrospray mass spectrometer (Micromass, Manchester , UK ). Column chromatography was carried out with Kieselgel silica (70–230 and 230–400 mesh, Merck, Darmstadt, Germany ), Sephadex® LH-20 (20–100 μm, Pharmacia, Uppsala , Sweden ), MCI-gel CHP 20P (75–150 μm, Mitsubishi Chemical, Tokyo , Japan ), and Cosmosil 75 C 18 - OPN (Nacalai Tesque, Kyoto , Japan ). High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) was performed using a Hitachi L-2130 ( Tokyo , Japan ) apparatus equipped with a refractometric detector (Hitachi L-2490). Purification by means of HPLC was conducted with a silica gel column (i.d. 10 × 250 mm , 5 μm, at a flow rate of 2 mL/min) (Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA ) for semipreparative and analytical HPLC, respectively. X-ray single-crystal diffraction was measured on a Siemens SMART CCD XRD (Siemens, Munich, Germany ).

sec.title: 4.2. Substrate 2
4.3. Microorganisms
sec.p:
Twenty microorganisms, obtained from the Division of Medicinal and Natural Products Chemistry, College of Pharmacy, University of Iowa ( Iowa City, IA, USA ) and the Bioresources Collection and Research Center (Hsinchu, Taiwan) were used for initial screening of 2 . The following is the microorganisms for screening to metabolize 2 :
Absidia pseudocylindrospora Hesseltine et Ellis
, teleomorph ( Cunninghamellaceae ) ATCC 24169,
Aspergillus niger Tiegh. (Aspergillaceae)
BCRC 32720,
Bacillus cereus UI 1477
,
Bacillus megaterium de Bary (Bacillaceae)
ATCC 14581,
Beauveria sulfurescens (Balsamo) Vuillemin (Moniliaceae)
ATCC 7159,
Cunninghamella blakesleeana Lendner (Cunninghamellaceae)
ATCC 8688a,
Cunninghamella bainieri Thaxter var. echinulate (Cunninghamellaceae)
ATCC 9244,
Cunninghamella elegans Lendner (Cunninghamellaceae)
ATCC 9245,
Mortierella isabellina Oudemans
, teleomorph ( Mortierellaceae ) ATCC 38063,
Mucor mucedo (Linnaeus) Fresenius
, teleomorph ( Mucoraceae ) ATCC 20094,
Mucor recurvatus MR
36,
Mucor mucedo UC
4605,
Nocardia aurantia (Zopf) Tsukamura emend. Rainey et al. (Nocardiaceae)
ATCC 12674,
Nocardia butanica (Zopf) Tsukamura emend. Rainey et al. (Nocardiaceae)
ATCC 21197,
Nocardia restricta (Magnusson) Goodfellow and Alderson (Nocardiaceae)
ATCC 14887,
Nocardia sp. (Nocardiaceae)
NRRL 5646,
Penicillum notatum Thom (Aspergillaceae)
ATCC 36740,
Pseudomonas putida (Trevisan) Migula (Pseudomonadaceae)
ATCC 33015,
Streptomyces griseus subsp. griseus (Krainsky) Waksman and Henrici (Streptomycetaceae)
ATCC 10137, and
Streptomyces griseus subsp. griseus (Krainsky) Waksman and Henrici (Streptomycetaceae)
ATCC 13273. Stock cultures were maintained on Sabouraud-maltose agar slants or those recommended by the ATCC and BCRC, stored at 4 ◦ C , and periodically subcultured.

sec.title: 4.4. Incubation and screening procedures
sec.p:
The fermentation protocol for screening was identical to that described previously (
). Culture controls and substrate controls were both performed using the same protocol. Ten specialized products were reproducibly produced by
A. niger BCRC
32720,
C. bainieri ATCC
9244, and
M. isabellina ATCC
38063.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 4.5. Preparative transformations of 2 by A. niger BCRC 32720, C. bainieri ATCC 9244, and M. isabellina ATCC 38063

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
A. niger
,
C. bainieri
, and
M. isabellina
were grown according to regular fermentation procedures (
). Using 24-h-old stage II cultures, a solution of 2 (1.00 g dissolved in 10 mL of DMF) was evenly distributed among 100 stainless-steel-capped 125-mL flasks containing stage II cultures. Substrate-containing cultures were incubated for 144 h. Extraction as previously described (
) produced 6.56 g of deep-brown oil, 5.04 g of deep-brown oil, and 7.50 g of deep-brown oil after respective bioconversions with
A. niger
,
C. bainieri
, and
M. isabellina
. Crude residues ( 6.56 g ) obtained from the liquid culture of
A. niger
were subjected to silica gel ( 110 g , 2.5 × 42 cm ) column chromatography eluted with mixtures of CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (500 mL each of 20:1, 16:1, 12:1, 8:1, and 6:1). The elutes were monitored using thin-layer chromatography (TLC). Five fractions (A E) were obtained on the basis of the TLC profile. Fraction E ( 507 mg ), a more-polar portion, was first applied to CC, over silica gel ( 45 g , 2 × 42 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (12:1) to obtain three fractions (E 1 E 3). With further chromatography of fraction E 2 ( 45 mg ) over silica gel ( 20 g , 1.2 × 36 cm ) elution with CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (10:1), 10 mg (yield: 1.1%) of 3 was obtained as a white powder. Fraction B ( 1.72 g ) was chromatographed over Sephadex LH-20 (3 × 45 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 to afford fraction B-1. Fraction B-1 ( 302 mg ) was rechromatographed over MCI-gel CHP 20P (2.5 × 40 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (2:3 to 4:1, v/v) to obtain 299 mg (recovery: 29.9%) of 2 and fraction B-1-1. Fraction B-1-1 ( 227 mg ) was applied to CC over silica gel ( 35 g , 1.8 × 36 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (30:1) to obtain fraction B-1-1a. After further chromatography of fraction B-1-1a ( 27 mg ) over MCI-gel CHP 20P (1.2 × 20 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:4 to 9:1, v/v), 5 was obtained. After recrystallization from CH 3 OH (10 mL), 8 mg (yield: 0.7%) of 5 was obtained as white needles. Fraction C ( 286 mg ) was chromatographed over Sephadex LH-20 (2.5 × 40 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 to afford two fractions (C-1 and C-2). Fraction C-2 ( 93 mg ) was rechromatographed over Sephadex LH-20 (2 × 28 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:1 to 4:1, v/v) to afford 4 . After recrystallization with ( CH 3 ) 2 CO hexane (2:8), 18 mg (yield: 1.9%) of 4 was obtained as white needles. Fraction D ( 128 mg ) was subjected to CC over silica gel ( 29 g , 1.8 × 28 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (16:1) to afford three fractions (D-1 D-3). With further chromatography of fraction D-2 ( 55 mg ) over MCI-gel CHP 20P (1.8 × 25 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (2:3 to 7:3, v/v), 6 was obtained. After recrystallization from ( CH 3 ) 2 CO–H 2 O (1:5), 43 mg (yield: 4.5%)of 6 was yielded as white crystals.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The crude residue from
C. bainieri
( 5.04 g ) was subjected to silica gel CC ( 110 g , 2.5 × 42 cm ). In total, eight fractions (A H) were eluted with mixtures of CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (600 mL each of 20:1, 16:1, 12:1, 8:1, and 6:1). The elutes were monitored using TLC. Fractions were combined on the basis of similar TLC profiles. With further chromatography of fraction B ( 629 mg ) over silica gel ( 50 g , 2 × 45 cm ) eluted with hexane-EtOAc (3:1), three subfractions (B-1 B-3) were yielded. Fraction B-2 ( 352 mg ) was rechromatographed over silica gel ( 35 g , 1.8 × 36 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (20:1) to recover 277 mg (27.7%) of 2 . Fraction C ( 971 mg ) was chromatographed over silica gel ( 120 g , 2.5 × 45 cm ) ( CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH with increasing polarity) to give 6 . After crystallization from ( CH 3 ) 2 CO–H 2 O (1:5), 109 mg (yield: 11.5%) of 6 was obtained as white needles. Fraction D ( 317 mg ) was chromatographed over silica gel ( 35 g , 1.8 × 36 cm ) ( CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH with increasing polarity) to give 7 . After crystallization with ( CH 3 ) 2 CO–H 2 O, 17 mg (yield: 1.9%) of 7 was obtained as white cubic crystals. Fraction E ( 445 mg ) was chromatographed over silica gel ( 45 g , 2 × 42 cm ) ( CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH with increasing polarity) to give fraction E 1. With further chromatography of fraction E 1 ( 197 mg ) over MCI-gel CHP 20P (2.5 × 40 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (2:3 to 4:1, v/v), 8 was obtained. After recrystallization from ( CH 3 ) 2 CO hexane (1:5), 13 mg (yield: 1.4%) of 8 was yielded as white needles. Fraction G ( 182 mg ) was chromatographed over silica gel ( 35 g , 1.8 × 36 cm ) ( CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH with increasing polarity) to give fraction G-1. With further chromatography of fraction G-1 ( 104 mg ) over Cosmosil C 18 -OPN (2 × 30 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:1), 9 was obtained. After recrystallization from CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:5), 14 mg (yield: 1.5%) of 9 was yielded as white cubic crystals. Fraction H ( 406 mg ) was chromatographed over silica gel ( 45 g , 2 × 42 cm ) ( CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH with increasing polarity) to give two fractions (H-1 and H-2). With further chromatography of fraction H-2 ( 178 mg ) over MCI-gel CHP 20P (2.5 × 40 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (2:3 to 9:1, v/v), fraction H-2a was obtained. Fraction H-2a ( 14 mg ) was applied to Cosmosil C 18 -OPN (2 × 20 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:1 to 3:2, v/v) to obtain 10 . After recrystallization from ( CH 3 ) 2 CO–H 2 O (1:5), 5 mg (yield: 0.5%) of 10 was yielded as white needles.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
The crude residue from
M. isabellina
( 7.50 g ) was subjected to silica gel ( 125 g , 2.5 × 45 cm ) CC. In total, 10 fractions (A J) were eluted with mixtures of CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (600 mL each of 20:1, 16:1, 12:1, 8:1, and 6:1). The elutes were monitored using TLC. Fractions were combined on the basis of similar TLC profiles. With further chromatography of fraction B ( 603 mg ) over Sephadex LH-20 (3 × 30 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl
2 , 189 mg
(yield: 18.9%) of 2 was recovered. Fraction C ( 43 mg ) was purified by HPLC ( CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH, 15:1, v/v) on a semi-preparative column (i.d. 10 × 250 mm , 5 μm, at a flow rate of 2 mL/min) to afford 9 ( 2 mg , t
R
=15.0 min; Fig. S42, Supplementary data). Fraction H ( 299 mg ) was chromatographed over Sephadex LH-20 (2.5 × 40 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 with increasing CH 3 OH to give three fractions (H-1 H-3). Further chromatography of fraction H-2 ( 92 mg ) over Cosmosil C 18 -OPN (2 × 30 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:4 to 4:1, v/v) produced two fractions (H-2a and H-2b). Fraction H-2a ( 15 mg ) was applied to CC over MCI-gel CHP 20P (1.8 × 20 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:1 to 7:3, v/ v) to give H-2a-1. With further chromatography of fraction H-2a-1 ( 8 mg ) over silica gel ( 12 g , 1 × 30 cm ) eluted with CH 2 Cl 2 – CH 3 OH (18:1), 2.5 mg of 9 was yielded. After fraction H-2b ( 36 mg ) was chromatographed over Cosmosil C 18 -OPN (2 × 30 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:4 to 2:3, v/v), 8 mg (yield: 0.8%) of 4 was obtained. Fraction I ( 1.14 g ) was chromatographed over MCI-gel CHP 20P (3 × 45 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (2:3 to 3:2, v/v) with increasing CH 3 OH to give three fractions (I-1 I-3). Fraction I-2 ( 373 mg ) was subjected to CC over Cosmosil C 18 -OPN (3 × 30 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:5 to 2:3, v/v) to obtain 11 . After recrystallization from CH 3 OH–H 2 O (1:5), 100 mg (yield: 10%) of 11 was yielded as white needles. Fraction I-3 ( 74 mg ) was also subjected to CC over Cosmosil C 18 -OPN (2 × 30 cm ) eluted with CH 3 OH–H 2 O (3:7 to 1:1, v/v) to yield 12 . After recrystallization from ( CH 3 ) 2 CO–H 2 O (1:5), 5 mg (yield: 0.5%) of 12 was yielded as white needles.

sec.title: 4.5.1. Compound 4
sec.p: White needles [( CH 3 ) 2 CO hexane]; mp 225–227 ◦ C ; [α] 25 D 60 ( c 0.55, CH 3 OH); IR (KBr) ν max 1731 ( C ––O), 1272 ( C –O– C ) cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 335.2229 [M + H] + (calcd for C 20 H 31 O 4 , 335.2222); m/z 333.2077 [M H] (calcd for C 20 H 29 O 4 , 333.2066).

sec.title: 4.5.2. X-ray crystallographic data for 4
sec.p:
Colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained via the slow evaporation of a CH 3 OH–H 2 O solution: C 20 H 30 O 4 ⋅H 2 O, M = 352.46, orthorhombic, space group P 212121 , a = 7.2617 (5) Å , b =13.0326 (6) Å , c =19.4965 (9) Å , V =1845.13 (17) Å 3 ; Z = 4, D calcd = 1.269 g cm 3 , crystal size: 0.20 × 0.15 × 0.10 mm 3 , F (000) = 768, λ (Mo Kα) = 1.54178 Å , T = 295(2) K, 5660 reflection collected. Final GooF = 0.997, final R indices
R 1
= 0.0354,
wR 2
= 0.1093, 235 parameters, μ = 0.724 mm 1 , R indices based on 3332 reflections with
I >
2σ( I ) absorption corrections applied. Complete crystallographic data of 4 were deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 2017519).

sec.title: 4.5.3. Compound 7
sec.p: White cubic crystals [( CH 3 ) 2 CO–H 2 O]; mp > 300 ◦ C ; [α] 25 D 33 ( c 0.57, CH 3 OH); IR (KBr) ν max 3419 (OH), 1735, 1707 ( C ––O) cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 373.2007 [M +Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 30 O 5 Na, 373.1991); m/z 349.2026 [M H] (calcd for C 20 H 29 O 5 , 349.2015).

sec.title: 4.5.4. X-ray crystallographic data for 7
sec.p:
Colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained via the slow evaporation of a CH 3 OH–H 2 O solution: C 20 H 30 O 5 , M =350.44, orthorhombic, space group P 212121 , a =8.7154 (4) Å , b = 9.0382 (4) Å , c = 22.5087 (9) Å , V = 1773.04 (13) Å 3 ; Z = 4, D calcd = 1.313 g cm 3 , crystal size: 0.25 × 0.20 × 0.15 mm 3 , F (000) = 760, λ (Mo Kα) = 1.54178 Å , T = 295(2) K, 7897 reflection collected. Final GooF = 1.093, final R indices
R 1
= 0.0608,
wR 2
= 0.1710, 227 parameters, μ = 0.753 mm 1 , R indices based on 3141 reflections with
I >
2σ( I ) absorption corrections applied. Complete crystallographic data of 7 were deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 2015840).

sec.title: 4.5.5. Compound 9
sec.p: White cubic crystals ( CH 3 OH–H 2 O); mp 220–222 ◦ C ; [α] 25 D 109 ( c 0.6, CH 3 OH); IR (KBr) ν max 3368 (OH), 1693 ( C ––O) cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 357.2030 [M + Na] + (calcd for C 20 H 30 O 4 Na, 357.2042); m/z 333.2057 [M H] (calcd for C 20 H 29 O 4 , 333.2066).

sec.title: 4.5.6. Compound 11
sec.p: White needles ( CH 3 OH–H 2 O); mp 289–291 ◦ C ; [α] 25 D 84 ( c 0.95, CH 3 OH); IR (KBr) ν max 3364 (OH), 1691 ( C ––O) cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR, see Table 1 ; HRESIMS m/z 335.2229 [M + H] + (calcd for C 20 H 31 O 4 , 335.2222).

sec.title: 4.5.7. X-ray crystallographic data for 11
sec.p:
Colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained via the slow evaporation of a CH 3 OH–H 2 O solution: C 20 H 30 O 4 , M = 334.44, monoclinic, space group P 21 , a = 12.3679 (13) Å , b = 10.9814 (7) Å , c =13.7648 (15) Å , V = 1774.5 (3) Å 3 ; Z = 4, D calcd = 1.252 g cm 3 , crystal size: 0.20 × 0.15 × 0.10 mm 3 , F (000) = 728, λ (Mo Kα) = 1.54178 Å , T = 295(2) K, 10775 reflection collected. Final GooF = 0.982, final R indices
R 1
= 0.0689,
wR 2
= 0.1777, 433 parameters, μ = 0.684 mm 1 , R indices based on 6274 reflections with
I >
2σ( I ) absorption corrections applied. Complete crystallographic data of 11 were deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC 2017865).

CCDC 2017519, 2015840, and 2017865 contain supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html, or from the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44 1223 336 033; e-mail: data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

sec.title: 4.6. Cell culture and treatment
sec.p:
The human monocytic THP-1 cell line was maintained at 37 ◦ C in 5% CO
2 in
RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (FBS), 2 mmol/L L-glutamine and 0.05 mM 2-mercaptoethanol, and was induced to differentiate into macrophages with 80 nM of phorbol 12-myristate-13-acetate (PMA) for three days. Differentiated cells were treated with 100 ng /mL LPS from
Escherichia coli
serotype 0111: B 4 (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA ) for 6 h following treatment with tested compounds at 10 μM or vehicle DMSO (the control group). Messenger (m)RNA levels of indicated cytokines were compared between the tested compound-treated groups and the control group after 24 h treatment.

sec.title: 4.7. Cell viability assays
sec.p: The cytotoxicity of tested compounds to PMA-differentiated THP-1 cells was assessed by the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl-2 H - tetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay. MTT was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA ; 98% purity), and dissolved as a 5 mg /mL stock solution. After 24 h of tested compound treatment, MTT at a final concentration of 0.5 mg /mL was added to cells and incubated at 37 ◦ C for 3 h. At the end of incubation, culture medium was removed, and 200 μL of DMSO (Sigma) was added to dissolve the blue formazan crystals. The absorbance was then measured using a model FLx800 Fluorescence Microplate Reader (BioTek Instruments, Winooski, Vermont , USA ) at 570 nm . Cell survival was expressed as a percentage of formazan absorbance, and normalized to the control (CTL) group. Results are presented as the mean value and standard deviation (SD) from three different experiments done in triplicate.

sec.title: 4.8. RNA isolation and reverse transcription quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) analyses
sec.p:
Total cellular RNA was isolated from cells using TRIzol reagent (Invitrogen) according to the manufacturer’ s protocol. The concentration was determined based on the absorbance at 260 nm , and first-strand complementary (c)DNA was synthesized from total RNA using the SuperScript II Reverse Transcriptase (RT) (Invitrogen) and Oligo(dT) primer. A qPCR was used to quantify the mRNA level of the target gene. Amplification was carried out using the ABI Prism 7300 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA, USA ). The reaction was performed in a 20-μL mixture containing 1 × reaction buffer (SYBR-Green Master Mixture; Applied Biosystems) and 100 nM of the primers: 5 ′ -GTCTGGGCAGGTCTACTTTGG-3 ′ (F) and 5 ′ -GAGGTTGAGGGTGTCTGAAGG-3 ′ (R) for tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α; 5 ′ - TGTGAAAGCAGCAAAGAGGCACTG-3 ′ (F) and 5 ′ -ACAGCTCTGGCTTGT TCCTCACTA-3 ′ (R) for interleukin (IL)-6; 5 ′ -GCTGAGGAAGATGCTGG TTC-3 ′ (F) and 5 ′ -CGTGCACATAAGCCTCGTTA-3 ′ (R) for IL-1β; and 5 ′ - CTGGAACGCTGAAGGTGACA-3 ′ (F) and 5 ′ -AAGGGACTTCCTGTAACAATGCA-3 ′ (R) for β- actin (the internal control). The specificity was verified by an additional dissociation curve. The interpolated number of cycles to reach a fixed threshold above background noise (Ct) was used to quantify the amplification. The mRNA expression was quantified by the ΔCt-method as described previously (
). Results are presented as average values from two independent experiments done in duplicate.

sec.title: 4.9. Immunoblotting
4.10. Membrane array analysis
sec.p: A human cytokine antibody array (Abcam, Cambridge, UK ) was used to compare cytokines secreted by THP-1 after treatment with indicated compounds. Supernatants from cultured cells were collected and applied to the cytokine array according to the manufacturer’ s protocol. Densitometry data were obtained with the UVP autochemiTM bioimaging system, and normalized as suggested in the manufacturer’ s protocol. Quantitative data shown are values relative to the LPS group.

sec.title: 4.11. Molecular docking studies
sec.p:
Molecular docking and scoring protocols were performed with the docking program, CDOCKER algorithm, in Discovery Studio 2017 (DS 2017) to investigate possible ligand-binding conformations within the GR binding pocket. The crystal structure of the GR-dexamethasone binding complex (PDB ID: 4UDC) (
), at a resolution of 2.5 Å , was downloaded from the RCSB Protein Data Bank. The structure and residues were refined in BIOVIA Discovery Studio 2017 (Biovia, San Diego, CA, USA ). Before the docking experiments, dexamethasone was removed from the refined 4UDC structure, and the binding site was defined as a sphere radius of 8 Å from the position of dexamethasone. Then a 3D ligand database of dexamethasone and compounds 1–12 was built as a total of 305 conformations with the best conformation settings. Docking programs consisting of scoring and search facilitates are used to find low free-energy binding poses. The interaction energies between proteins and ligands were calculated with the CHARMm force field. The resulting poses of each trial were ranked by their energies that included the intra-interaction energy of the ligand and the interaction energy between the ligand and protein. CDOCKER embedded in DS 2017 was used for accurate and precise flexible docking. Each compound was employed for molecular docking experiments and data analyses. Most of the docking parameters were set to defaults for CDOCKER. The top ten CDOCKER energy analyses were collected from each compound for analysis. Potential activators were selected based on the CDOCKER interaction energy formed between compounds 1–12 and GR.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: This work was financially supported by the University System of the Taipei Joint Research Program (USTP-NTUT-TMU-105-05) and the Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST 107-2635- B- 038-001) in Taiwan . We are indebted to Dr. John P. N. Rosazza, Division of Medicinal and Natural Products Chemistry, College of Pharmacy, University of Iowa , Iowa City, IA, USA , for kindly providing the microbial strains. The authors acknowledge the technical support provided by TMU Core Facility. We would like to acknowledge Szu-Hung Chen and Ming-Rui Chang for assistance in conducting molecular docking at the Institute of Biochemical and Biomedical Engineering, National Taipei University of Technology, Taipei , Taiwan .

sec.title: Appendix A . Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112776.
Author contributions

Shwu-Fen Chang, performed biological experiments. Hsuan-Liang Liu, conceived and designed research, conducted molecular docking studies. Yih Ho, conducted molecular docking studies. Li-Ming Yang, conducted experiments and analyzed data. Ya-En Tsai, conducted experiments and analyzed data. Bo-Hon Chou, conducted experiments and analyzed data. Shwu-Huey Wang, conducted experiments and analyzed data. Shwu-Jiuan Lin, conceived and designed research, supervised the experiments and wrote and revised the manuscript.
